content.raw:
Thanks for checking. You can try with Bullet to see that the missing features list decreases. Another thing to check is that all features being made optional still work with DART. 

Checking with TPE would be good, but it will just print a different list of missing features. So maybe it's not worth the effort right now.

I think the main thing to check in this PR is whether the general approach is ok. I'll open new PRs to make all the features missing from TPE optional.

content.raw: This looks great! I like how casts are cached so that they don't hurt performance. I wanted to point out that it's not just the `MinimumFeatureList` that should not be modified. Even the `DetachableJointFeatureList` is now part of the ABI because adding a feature to it would break physics engine plugins that once worked. So if we really needed to add a feature to `DetachableJointFeatureList`, I guess we'll have to have another list, maybe `DetachableJointFeatureListWithNewFeature` and have some logic that tries to cast to `DetachableJointFeatureListWithNewFeature` first then fallback to `DetachableJointFeatureList`. I really hope it doesn't come to that though :fingers_crossed:
content.html: This looks great! I like how casts are cached so that they don't hurt performance. I wanted to point out that it's not just the MinimumFeatureList that should not be modified. Even the DetachableJointFeatureList is now part of the ABI because adding a feature to it would break physics engine plugins that once worked. So if we really needed to add a feature to DetachableJointFeatureList, I guess we'll have to have another list, maybe DetachableJointFeatureListWithNewFeature and have some logic that tries to cast to DetachableJointFeatureListWithNewFeature first then fallback to DetachableJointFeatureList. I really hope it doesn't come to that though

content.raw:
To be clear, the ABI wouldn’t break by adding a new feature to the feature list. It would just potentially change which plugins qualify as satisfying the `MinimumFeatureList`.

I do think it’s best to keep the minimum feature list frozen, because we don’t want plugin developers to have a moving target that they need their plugins to qualify for. If a new feature needs to be added, it could be handled as its own independent feature branch within the physics system. That branch could simply contain a set of `Model3dPtr<FeatureList<DetachableJointFeature>>` \(not a feature list that combines `MinimumFeatureList` \+ `DetachableJointFeature`, but just the `DetachableJointFeature` API alone\), and that branch only concerns itself with commands related to joints detaching.
content.html:
To be clear, the ABI wouldn’t break by adding a new feature to the feature list. It would just potentially change which plugins qualify as satisfying the MinimumFeatureList.

I do think it’s best to keep the minimum feature list frozen, because we don’t want plugin developers to have a moving target that they need their plugins to qualify for. If a new feature needs to be added, it could be handled as its own independent feature branch within the physics system. That branch could simply contain a set of Model3dPtr<FeatureList<DetachableJointFeature>> (not a feature list that combines MinimumFeatureList + DetachableJointFeature, but just the DetachableJointFeature API alone), and that branch only concerns itself with commands related to joints detaching.

content.raw:
> not a feature list that combines MinimumFeatureList + DetachableJointFeature

Yeah the only reason I added `MinimumFeatureList` there is because while processing detachable joints, we also need some core joint features, and it's more convenient to use the same pointer for everything. Let me know if there's a downside to this.

For TPE, I also made joints optional on [this branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/branch/chapulina/tpe?dest=chapulina%2Fbullet_citadel#diff), so the detachable joints extend `JointFeatureList` instead of `MinimumFeatureList`.
content.html:
not a feature list that combines MinimumFeatureList + DetachableJointFeature

Yeah the only reason I added MinimumFeatureList there is because while processing detachable joints, we also need some core joint features, and it's more convenient to use the same pointer for everything. Let me know if there's a downside to this.

For TPE, I also made joints optional on this branch, so the detachable joints extend JointFeatureList instead of MinimumFeatureList.

content.raw:
The biggest downside is it will increase compilation times. The best practice for the sake of compilation times is to only specify the features that you need. If the implementation of the joint removal ever changes in the future and you need more of the features, it’s okay to expand the feature list as needed; that won’t have any negative consequences, as long as the object isn’t being exposed in a public API.

There’s also some very slight increase in the amount of time it might take to cast the entity type, but that will be completely unnoticeable if the casted entities are being cached.

So mostly it comes down to a trade off between developer expediency and compilation times, much like using `#include` to pull in a “master” header that aggregates other headers that you don’t really need.
content.html:
The biggest downside is it will increase compilation times. The best practice for the sake of compilation times is to only specify the features that you need. If the implementation of the joint removal ever changes in the future and you need more of the features, it’s okay to expand the feature list as needed; that won’t have any negative consequences, as long as the object isn’t being exposed in a public API.

There’s also some very slight increase in the amount of time it might take to cast the entity type, but that will be completely unnoticeable if the casted entities are being cached.

So mostly it comes down to a trade off between developer expediency and compilation times, much like using #include to pull in a “master” header that aggregates other headers that you don’t really need.

content.raw:
>  a trade off between developer expediency and compilation times

I think there's another variable to add to the trade-offs: _runtime performance_. Removing `MinimumFeatureList` from `DetachableJointList` would add 2 `RequestFeatures` calls whenever we create a detachable joint, one for the child link, the other for the joint. 

So I think for now the scale is tipping towards keeping the `MinimumFeatureList` there for now. Once all joint features are removed from `MinimumFeatureList`, the impact on compilation time should be decreased.
content.html:
a trade off between developer expediency and compilation times

I think there's another variable to add to the trade-offs: runtime performance. Removing MinimumFeatureList from DetachableJointList would add 2 RequestFeatures calls whenever we create a detachable joint, one for the child link, the other for the joint.

So I think for now the scale is tipping towards keeping the MinimumFeatureList there for now. Once all joint features are removed from MinimumFeatureList, the impact on compilation time should be decreased.

content.raw: It's the bounding box, I'm checking.

I can't reproduce the test failure using clang on Linux. I made the test verbose on 105475d so we can get more info from Jenkins logs.

Here's a build I had triggered before making the test verbose: [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/2883/badge/icon)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/2883/)

And I triggered a new one to be verbose: [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/2885/badge/icon)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-homebrew-amd64/2885/)

If these pass, I think we can consider the test flaky and merge.

If at least one of them fails, I think we should decline this PR and revisit on GitHub.

Let me know what you think.

content.raw:
I’m not 100% clear on why an additional `RequestFeatures` would be needed, but the runtime cost of it should be unnoticeable if the casted entities are being cached.

Either way, this is probably a premature optimization concern. I’d say whenever there’s a need in the future to audit the compilation times, this would be a prime candidate to look at.

Either way, this is probably a premature optimization concern. I’d say whenever there’s a need in the future to audit the compilation times, this would be a prime candidate to look at.
